Netrunner Comprehensive Rules

Null Signal Games

This rules document is to be used as reference material. It is not intended to be read straight through. If you still have questions after consulting this document, please ask us online via email. This version of the Comprehensive Rules document is effective 28 April 2025.

Summary of Changes (v25.04)
  • Remove "potential to change the game state" requirement from section 1.2 and section 9.1.
  • Add section 9.5.6 for abilities that can only be triggered in specific situations.
  • Update rule 1.3.7 to better represent how the [MU] symbol is used in card text.
  • Make rule 1.5.4d more general to account for a new double-sided Runner identity.
  • Cleared up duplicate definitions of the flatline condition for negative maximum hand size. The main reference is rule 1.7.2b.
  • Add rule 1.12.6a to clarify that an object can still be the source of lingering effects after it ceases to exist.
  • Update and add examples to rule 1.13.11 to clarify the exception when agendas move between score areas.
  • Expand section 1.13.2 to make rule 1.13.2a its own rule and give it clearer wording.
  • Add rule 1.13.2b to clarify that cards like Film Critic and Cupellation uninstall Corp cards that become hosted on them.
  • Add rule 1.13.2c to clarify that installing a card that was hosted on another card ends the relationship to its former host.
  • Add rule 1.16.2e to codify the ability on Biawak.
  • Add rule 1.16.2f to codify how to apply a reduction in the "total" cost of an "install and rez" effect.
  • Add clarification in rule 1.16.3a that a checkpoint occurs even when the cost is 0.
  • Update section 1.20 to better define phrases like "unused [MU]" and "[MU] is full". Add section 1.20.4 to codify abilities that restrict how [MU] can be used.
  • Update the descriptions in section 2 for the new card frames.
  • Update list of subtypes section 2.16.7 to add unsubstantiated and expand deep net to new card types.
  • Add an explicit timing step for "action phase ends" abilities to meet their trigger condition, at step 5.6.2d for the Corp's turn and step 5.7.1h for the Runner's turn.
  • Update section 5.4.3 to cover how terminal operations interact with "action phase ends" trigger conditions.
  • Add rule 5.4.4 to address the case where a terminal operation resolves outside of its controller's action phase.
  • Organize the discard step rules under section 5.5.4.
  • Overhaul section 6.2. Ice positions are now handled as an explicit game construct, which simplifies cases where ice movements affect the progression of a run. If the Runner is occupying the position of a piece of ice that is uninstalled or moved, that position now continues to exist until the Runner leaves it normally, rather than immediately "collapsing" the server and forcing the current timing step of the run to be changed.
  • Add step 10.3.1i to clean up empty positions during checkpoints.
  • Add a paid ability window in the Initiation Phase at step 6.9.1e. Add step 6.9.1d to set the initial position of the Runner immediately before the new paid ability window.
  • Clarify that rule 6.2.7b applies to swaps from other zones as well as swaps with other installed ice.
  • Update rule 8.3.3 to clarify that facedown cards cannot be looked at by their controller while they are being (re-)arranged by their opponent.
  • Add section 8.5.15 to clarify how to resolve an "install and rez" instruction.
  • Add rule 8.5.15a to clarify installing and rezzing multiple cards at once.
  • Add section 8.6.6 to list cases where an event or operation is not trashed after resolving it. Add rule 8.6.6d to cover the new case of abilities that play an operation and remove it from the game afterward.
  • Add the "once per turn" ability flag in section 9.3.6.
  • Update rule 9.6.5b to be more precise in its language, and add examples.
  • Update outdated example about play abilities in rule 9.7.1.
  • Remove the rule about static abilities in section 9.9.5. All cards that previously used a static ability to apply a prevention effect have received updates to their official text and now use a conditional ability interrupt instead.
  • Add an example to rule 9.9.7b.
  • Add rule 9.9.7f to clarify how Guru Davinder interacts with other interrupt abilities.
  • Add section 10.13 detailing the Dividends keyword.
Acknowledgements
  • Netrunner Original Game Design: Richard Garfield
  • Android: Netrunner
    • Game Development: Lukas Litzsinger
    • Expansion Development: Lukas Litzsinger, Damon Stone, and Michael Boggs
    • Rules by: Adam Baker, Michael Boggs, and Erik Dahlman
    • Android Universe created by: Kevin Wilson with Daniel Lovat Clark
  • Null Signal Games
    • Rules Manager: Jamie Perconti
    • Rules Associates: Ruben P. Pieters and Justin Prentice
    • Rules Editors: Jonny Foster
    • Additional Contributions: Kayli Ammen, Noah Bogart, Pat Chapman, Tim Vaduva, and Olive Wesley
  • Github Repository Contributions: lostgeek, plural, and qwitwa

Netrunner is a ™ of R. Talsorian Games, Inc. Android is ™ & © Fantasy Flight Games. Although these rules are made to be compatible with cards from Android: Netrunner, they are not in any way associated with or endorsed by Fantasy Flight Games, R. Talsorian Games, or Wizards of the Coast.

1. Game Conceptslink

1.1. Generallink

These rules are compatible with cards from the game android: netrunner by Fantasy Flight Games. android: netrunner is a game about the cyber-struggle between massive Corporations and subversive hackers known as Runners.

  1. 1.1.1.linkThe game is played between two players. One player takes the role of the Corp (Corporation) and the other takes the role of the Runner. This rules document will frequently refer to a player interchangeably with their game role.
    1. 1.1.2.linkEach player needs a legal deck, an identity card for their role, and any extra cards used from outside their deck. They also need a supply of tokens as described in section 1.9. The constraints that define the legality of a deck are defined in section 1.4, and the cases where cards outside the deck and identity can be used are defined in section 1.5.
      1. 1.1.3.linkAll numbers used in the game are integers. Unless otherwise stated, a given value can be positive, negative, or zero.

        1.2. Golden Ruleslink

        1. 1.2.1.linkIf the text of a card directly contradicts these rules, the text of the card takes precedence.
          1. 1.2.2.linkIf a rule or ability directs something to happen, but another effect states that it cannot happen, the "cannot" ability takes precedence.
            1. 1.2.3.linkIf an instruction includes the words "if able," it can only be carried out fully or not at all. If any part of the instruction is not possible to carry out, the entire instruction is ignored.
              1. 1.2.4.linkIf an instruction does not include the words "if able," as much of that instruction as possible is carried out. Any parts of the instruction that are not possible to carry out are ignored.

                1.3. Symbolslink

                1. 1.3.1.linkSeveral non-English symbols appear on cards and in this rules document. This section serves as a basic guide to those symbols.
                  1. 1.3.2.linkWhen this document is presented in a format without images, plaintext replacements are used. These replacements are listed along with the symbols themselves for reference.
                    1. 1.3.3.linkThe symbol [c] (plaintext: [c]) stands for "credit". It always appears with a quantity, such as 1[c], which means "one credit," or 3[c], which means "three credits." See section 1.10 for rules about credits.
                      1. 1.3.4.linkThe symbol [click] (plaintext: [click]) stands for "click". Multiple clicks can be represented either by multiple symbols, such as [click][click], or by a numeral and symbol, such as 2[click], both meaning "two clicks." See section 1.11 for rules about clicks.
                        1. 1.3.5.linkThe symbol [recurring] (plaintext: [recurring]) stands for recurring credit. It always appears with a quantity, such as 1[recurring], which means "one recurring credit," or 3[recurring], which means "three recurring credits." See section 1.10.5 for rules about recurring credits.
                          1. 1.3.6.linkThe symbol [link] (plaintext: [link]) stands for "link". It is always used with a quantity, such as 1[link], which means "1 link." See section 10.7 for rules about link.
                            1. 1.3.7.linkThe symbol [MU] (plaintext: [MU]) stands for "memory" and also represents the unit used to measure memory. When used with a quantity, it should be read as "memory units". For example, 2[MU] means "2 memory units." See section 1.20 for rules about memory.
                              1. 1.3.8.linkThe symbol [sub] (plaintext: [sub]) stands for "subroutine". Each symbol marks a single subroutine on a piece of ice. See section 9.8 for information about subroutines.
                                1. 1.3.9.linkThe symbol [trash] (plaintext: [trash]) stands for "trash this card". It is used as a self-referential cost in card text, such as "[trash]: Draw 2 cards," which means "Trash this card to draw 2 cards." See section 1.16 for rules about costs, and section 1.19 for rules about trashing cards.
                                  1. 1.3.10.linkThe symbol [interrupt] (plaintext: [interrupt]) stands for "interrupt timing". It is used to designate abilities that resolve immediately before other abilities. See section 9.9 for rules about interrupt abilities.

                                    1.4. Deck Constructionlink

                                    1. 1.4.1.linkEach player's deck is associated with a single identity card that determines the faction, minimum deck size, and influence limit of that deck. The identity card may also stipulate other variances from the standard deckbuilding rules.
                                        1. a.linkThe identities The Catalyst and The Syndicate from the System Gateway Starter Pack are intended for use only with the decks included in that pack. They are not legal for play under the full deck construction rules.
                                        2. 1.4.2.linkEach deck must meet all requirements in this section to be legal for play.
                                          1. 1.4.3.linkThe deck must contain at least as many cards as the minimum deck size indicated on the corresponding identity.
                                              1. a.linkIdentity cards, extra cards that begin the game outside the deck, and player aid cards are not part of the deck and are not counted towards the size of the deck.
                                                1. b.linkThere is no maximum deck size.
                                                2. 1.4.4.linkDecks cannot contain identity cards, player aid cards, cards from the wrong side (Corp cards in a Runner deck or vice-versa), or out-of-faction cards that lack influence costs.
                                                  1. 1.4.5.linkNeutral cards and cards that belong to a faction other than the corresponding identity's faction are all considered out-of-faction. The total influence cost of out-of-faction cards in the deck must not exceed the influence limit of that identity.
                                                      1. a.linkThe total influence cost of out-of-faction cards is counted by copy and not by name.
                                                        1. Example: Including a single copy of Diesel in a non-Shaper deck adds 2 to the total influence in that deck, while including two copies of Diesel in a non-Shaper deck adds 4 to the total influence in that deck.
                                                    1. 1.4.6.linkA Corp deck must contain agendas totalling a certain number of agenda points, as determined by the total number of cards in the deck.
                                                        1. a.linkA deck with 40 to 44 cards must contain 18 or 19 agenda points.
                                                          1. b.linkA deck with 45 to 49 cards must contain 20 or 21 agenda points.
                                                            1. c.linkA deck with 50 to 54 cards must contain 22 or 23 agenda points.
                                                              1. d.linkA deck with more than 54 cards must contain 22 or 23 agenda points, plus an additional 2 agenda points for every full 5 cards in the deck over 50.
                                                                1. Example: A 66 card deck requires 6 additional agenda points, since it includes 3 sets of 5 cards beyond 50. This gives a final requirement of either 28 or 29 agenda points.
                                                            2. 1.4.7.linkThe deck cannot contain more than 3 copies of any single card, by name. Some cards stipulate alternative copy limits in their card text.
                                                              1. 1.4.8.linkTournament play may impose other restrictions or requirements on the legal configurations of identities and decks.

                                                                1.5. Extra Cardslink

                                                                1. 1.5.1.linkSome abilities allow for the use of additional cards from outside the deck.
                                                                  1. 1.5.2.linkOne Corp identity, Jinteki Biotech: Life Imagined, has the ability, "Before taking your first turn, you may switch this card with any copy of Jinteki Biotech." There are 3 versions of this identity, which have different abilities on their reverse side.
                                                                      1. a.linkA player playing Jinteki Biotech as their identity may bring any number of copies of that identity along with their deck. After completing game setup, that player may choose any copy they own to be their active identity for the duration of the game. All other copies are placed outside the game.
                                                                      2. 1.5.3.linkOne Runner identity, Adam: Compulsive Hacker, has the ability, "You start the game with 3 different directive cards installed (these cards are not considered part of your deck)."
                                                                          1. a.linkA player playing Adam as their identity must bring at least 3 differently named cards with the directive subtype along with their deck. The player may bring any number of directive cards over the required 3.
                                                                            1. b.linkAfter players reveal their identities, the player playing Adam selects exactly 3 of their provided directive cards. Those cards begin the game installed in the play area. All other directives the player brought this way remain outside the game.
                                                                              1. c.linkA player playing Adam can also include directive cards in their deck. The cards chosen to be installed at the beginning of the game do not impact the deck's influence requirements or the maximum allowed number of copies of those cards.
                                                                                1. d.linkOnce the game has begun, the cards installed this way are treated exactly as any other installed cards. Abilities that move these cards to other zones function normally, including shuffling them into the stack.
                                                                                2. 1.5.4.linkTwo cards, Rebirth and DJ Fenris, make use of identity cards other than the one selected by the player during deck construction.
                                                                                    1. a.linkA player may bring any number of additional Runner identity cards along with their deck. These cards are kept in a pile outside the game. The Runner may look at these cards at any time.
                                                                                      1. b.linkWhen an ability refers to an identity other than the Runner's current identity, it refers to the cards provided this way. If an identity card leaves the play area, it must be returned to the pile outside the game.
                                                                                        1. c.linkIn a tournament, all identities brought to the game this way must be legal for players to use as their actual identity in that tournament.
                                                                                          1. d.linkIf the Runner switches their identity with a double-sided identity, it enters play with the front side faceup. If the Runner switches a double-sided identity with another identity, the new identity enters play faceup regardless of the previous identity's current status.

                                                                                          1.6. Starting the Gamelink

                                                                                          1. 1.6.1.linkThe players decide who will play as the Corp and who will play as the Runner. Each player places an appropriate identity card for the side they are to play faceup in the play area, then supplies a corresponding deck, placing it facedown in the play area, and any appropriate extra cards.
                                                                                              1. a.linkSome identity cards have abilities that affect setup. Even though cards are not active until the game begins, these identities still alter setup at the appropriate step as indicated by their text.
                                                                                                1. b.linkSome identities are double-sided (see section 3.1). If a player is playing a double-sided identity, it begins the game with the front side faceup.
                                                                                                2. 1.6.2.linkIf a player's identity has an ability that affects setup or the start of the game, and that ability does not directly correspond to a setup step outlined in this section of the rules, that player makes any necessary decisions and changes for their identity's special setup or start of game abilities at this time. If both players have setup or start of game abilities at this time, the Corp resolves theirs first.
                                                                                                  1. 1.6.3.linkThe players create the bank by gathering all types of tokens described in section 1.9.
                                                                                                    1. 1.6.4.linkEach player takes five credits from the bank, placing the credits in their credit pool.
                                                                                                      1. 1.6.5.linkEach player shuffles their deck.
                                                                                                        1. 1.6.6.linkEach player draws 5 cards from the top of their deck to form their starting hand.
                                                                                                            1. a.linkAfter drawing starting hands, the Corp may choose to take a mulligan; then, the Runner may choose to take a mulligan. To take a mulligan, the player shuffles their starting hand back into their deck, then draws a new starting hand. They must keep the second hand as their starting hand.
                                                                                                            2. 1.6.7.linkThe game begins and the Corp takes their first turn.
                                                                                                                1. a.linkIf the Corp's identity has an ability with instructions for "before taking your first turn," the Corp resolves that ability immediately before taking their first turn, and thus before the game starts.

                                                                                                                1.7. Ending the Gamelink

                                                                                                                1. 1.7.1.linkThe game ends when a player meets one of their win conditions.
                                                                                                                    1. a.linkIf both players would simultaneously satisfy their win conditions, the game ends in a draw.
                                                                                                                    2. 1.7.2.linkEach player has two possible win conditions available.
                                                                                                                        1. a.linkEither player can win by collecting agenda points in their score area (usually done by scoring or stealing agendas; see section 1.17). A player with a score of 7 or more wins the game.
                                                                                                                          1. b.linkThe Corp wins if the Runner is flatlined. The Runner is flatlined immediately if they suffer more damage than they have cards in their grip. See section 10.4 for information about damage. The Runner is also flatlined if, at the beginning of their discard step, their maximum hand size is less than 0. See section 5.5 for information about maximum hand size and the discard step.
                                                                                                                            1. c.linkThe Runner wins if the Corp is required to draw a card from R&D but cannot because R&D is empty.

                                                                                                                            1.8. Cardslink

                                                                                                                            1. 1.8.1.linkThere are six types of Corp cards: agendas, assets, ice, identities, operations, and upgrades. All cards except the identity card are shuffled into the Corp's deck at the beginning of the game.
                                                                                                                              1. 1.8.2.linkThere are five types of Runner cards: events, hardware, identities, programs, and resources. All cards except the identity card are shuffled into the Runner's deck at the beginning of the game.
                                                                                                                                1. 1.8.3.linkCards that are active are able to affect the game through their abilities.
                                                                                                                                    1. a.linkRunner cards that are installed and faceup in the play area, Corp cards that are installed and rezzed, events and operations in the play area, agendas in the Corp's score area, and both players' identities are active.
                                                                                                                                      1. b.linkUnless otherwise stated, Runner cards become active as part of the process of playing or installing them.
                                                                                                                                        1. c.linkUnless otherwise stated, Corp cards other than operations are installed unrezzed, and thus inactive, into the play area. Assets, ice, and upgrades become active when they are rezzed; agendas become active when they are scored. Operations become active as part of the process of playing them.
                                                                                                                                          1. d.linkIdentity cards become active when the game begins.
                                                                                                                                          2. 1.8.4.linkCards that are inactive are unable to affect the game or have most of their abilities used.
                                                                                                                                              1. a.linkCards are inactive in R&D, HQ, Archives, the heap, the grip, the stack, the Runner's score area, while set aside, and while removed from the game. Facedown cards in the play area are also inactive.
                                                                                                                                                1. b.linkInactive cards in most zones retain their printed characteristics (name, card type, faction, cost, subtypes, influence, etc). Facedown installed Runner cards have no characteristics.
                                                                                                                                                2. 1.8.5.linkFor a player to draw 1 or more cards is to take that many cards from the top of their deck and put them into their hand. Section 8.4 provides more details about drawing cards.
                                                                                                                                                  1. 1.8.6.linkMost abilities are active if and only if the card they appear on is active. Section 9.1.8 details the cases where abilities on inactive cards are still active.
                                                                                                                                                    1. 1.8.7.linkAbilities can convert cards from one type into another type, or even from a card into a counter. Rules 10.1.3 and 10.1.4 explain the details of card conversion.

                                                                                                                                                      1.9. Counters and Tokenslink

                                                                                                                                                      1. 1.9.1.linkCounters and tokens are game pieces (or equivalent) that track various resources, effects, and statuses of players and their cards.
                                                                                                                                                          1. a.linkThe terms "counter" and "token" are interchangeable.
                                                                                                                                                          2. 1.9.2.linkThe bank is the supply of counters not yet in play. Counters in the bank are available to both players to take and use as dictated by the game rules and card abilities. Players do not control counters in the bank and cannot spend them. The bank is an unlimited supply; running out of game pieces to track a type of counter does not prohibit a player from gaining counters of that type or placing them on cards.
                                                                                                                                                              1. a.linkIf an instruction directs players to place counters on a card without designating where those counters come from, take those counters from the bank.
                                                                                                                                                                1. b.linkA condition or restriction that looks for counters being placed on a card can be met by either counters from the bank or counters moved from another location.
                                                                                                                                                                2. 1.9.3.linkSome abilities can convert a card into a counter. A counter put into play in this way is tracked with the card acting as a game piece. See rule 10.1.4.
                                                                                                                                                                  1. 1.9.4.linkSome abilities can cause a player or card to have or be "considered to have" 1 or more counters or additional counters without placing or giving those counters. A counter considered to exist in this way conveys all the same information and effects as a counter of the specified type would, except that it cannot be moved or removed from the card or player it belongs to, nor can it be spent to pay a cost.
                                                                                                                                                                    1. 1.9.5.linkThere are ten types of counters: credit counters, click counters, tag counters, bad publicity counters, core damage counters, advancement counters, virus counters, power counters, agenda counters, and condition counters.
                                                                                                                                                                        1. a.linkCredit counters are used to track the number of credits each player has in their credit pool; they can also be placed on cards. Rules for credits, the credit pool, and other related concepts are in section 1.10.
                                                                                                                                                                          1. b.linkClick counters are a gameplay aid used to track the clicks the active player has spent or has left to spend during their turn. Rules for clicks are in section 1.11.
                                                                                                                                                                            1. c.linkTag counters are used to represent tags on the Runner. Rules for tags are given in section 10.5.
                                                                                                                                                                              1. d.linkBad publicity counters represent bad publicity the Corp has earned. Rules for bad publicity are in section 10.6.
                                                                                                                                                                                1. e.linkCore damage counters are a gameplay aid used to track core damage the Runner has suffered. Each point of core damage the Runner suffers forces them to take a core damage counter. See section 10.4.
                                                                                                                                                                                  1. f.linkAdvancement counters are a counter used primarily on installed agendas to track the Corp's progress toward being able to score them.
                                                                                                                                                                                    1. g.linkVirus counters are a generic counter, used primarily by virus programs, that can be removed by the Corp purging them. See rule 10.1.2.
                                                                                                                                                                                      1. h.linkPower counters are a generic counter used by a variety of cards. They have no special rules.
                                                                                                                                                                                        1. i.linkAgenda counters are a generic counter used primarily on scored agendas. They have no special rules.
                                                                                                                                                                                          1. j.linkCondition counters are counters that have rules text. Their abilities are active as long as they are hosted on a card.

                                                                                                                                                                                          1.10. Creditslink

                                                                                                                                                                                          Each of the Runner's credits represents enough money to upgrade some basic parts for their console, have a meal at a decent restaurant, or buy a ticket and some concessions for a night at the sensies. Each of the Corp's credits represents enough money to manufacture a run of computer parts, buy out a decent restaurant, or film a low-budget sensie.

                                                                                                                                                                                          1. 1.10.1.linkA credit ([c]) is the basic unit of currency. Players spend their credits to pay for various costs, card abilities, traces, etc. Credit counters most commonly represent 1[c] each, but can represent larger denominations if clearly marked.
                                                                                                                                                                                            1. 1.10.2.linkEach player has a credit pool where they keep a supply of credit counters matching the credits they have available to spend. The number of credits in a player's credit pool is open information.
                                                                                                                                                                                              1. 1.10.3.linkCredits enter and leave a player's credit pool as that player gains, loses, or spends credits.
                                                                                                                                                                                                  1. a.linkA player gains credits whenever credits enter their credit pool from any location.
                                                                                                                                                                                                    1. b.linkIf a player is required to lose credits, that player is forced to move the specified number of credits from their credit pool to the bank. Players cannot lose credits from cards.
                                                                                                                                                                                                      1. Example: If a subroutine on DNA Tracker resolves, the Runner must lose 2[c] from their credit pool, or 1[c] if that is all they have. If the Runner's credit pool is empty, the effect does nothing.
                                                                                                                                                                                                    2. c.linkTo spend or pay credits, a player puts the specified number of credits back into the bank. By default, the credits must come from the player's credit pool. Abilities can also allow players to spend credits hosted on their cards under certain conditions. If any such abilities apply, the player chooses how to divide the credits they are spending from among the allowed locations. The terms "spend" and "pay" are synonymous.
                                                                                                                                                                                                      1. Example: The Runner may use the credit from Cyberfeeder to pay for Atman's first ability.
                                                                                                                                                                                                      2. Example: The Runner may use credits from Ghost Runner when secretly spending credits to resolve a Psi ability (such as The Future Perfect).
                                                                                                                                                                                                      3. Example: The Runner must use credits from Ghost Runner if this is the only way for them to pay 3[c] when resolving the "when encountered" ability on Tollbooth.
                                                                                                                                                                                                  2. 1.10.4.linkAbilities can place credits on cards, as discussed in section 1.13. Credits on a player's card are not in that player's credit pool; the player can only interact with those credits as instructed by card abilities.
                                                                                                                                                                                                      1. a.linkIf a player is instructed to take credits from a card, they remove that many credits from that card and gain those credits.
                                                                                                                                                                                                        1. b.linkIf an ability specifies how a player is allowed to spend credits from a card, they can be spent from that card as if they were in the player's credit pool for the specified actions or abilities.
                                                                                                                                                                                                          1. c.linkIf an ability specifies a time period during which a player is allowed to spend credits from a card, they can be spent from that card as if they were in the player's credit pool for any purpose (other than losing credits) as long as the specified time period is active or the specified duration has not expired.
                                                                                                                                                                                                            1. d.linkSpending credits from a card is considered "using" the card that allowed those credits to be spent. See section 9.1.6.
                                                                                                                                                                                                            2. 1.10.5.linkRecurring Credits
                                                                                                                                                                                                                1. a.linkRecurring Credits ([recurring]) place credits on a card repeatedly. The text "N[recurring]" means "When this card becomes active, place N credits on it. Before abilities meet their trigger conditions for your turn beginning, if there are fewer than N credits on this card, place credits on it until there are N credits on it."
                                                                                                                                                                                                                  1. b.linkRecurring credits are first placed on a card as soon as it becomes active. This occurs at step 8.5.16e of installing the card if it is installed active, step 8.6.7c of playing an event or operation, or as soon as the card is turned faceup or scored, as applicable.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                    1. c.linkRecurring credits are refilled during step 5.6.1c of the Corp's turn and step 5.7.1c of the Runner's turn, before other abilities that apply at the start of the turn resolve.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                      1. d.linkRecurring credits do not accumulate. They are refilled only up to the indicated number.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                        1. Example: The Runner installs Spinal Modem, which has 2[recurring]. 2 credits are placed on Spinal Modem now. The Runner spends 1 of those credits later in their turn. At the beginning of the Runner's next turn, the credits on Spinal Modem should be replenished up to 2[c], so 1 more credit is placed on it.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                    1.11. Clickslink

                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Working a job, making connections, and especially jacking in—everything you do takes time, and it always goes by faster than you think. A click represents an abstract amount of time spent on a particular activity, either several hours all at once or scattered across the day.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                    1. 1.11.1.linkA click ([click]) is the basic unit of activity. Players spend their clicks to perform actions and trigger abilities. Each click counter represents 1 click.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                      1. 1.11.2.linkAs the first step of a player's turn, they gain an allotted number of clicks to spend during the action phase of that turn. See section 5 for details about the procedures of player turns.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                          1. a.linkThe Corp receives 3[click] on each of their turns.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                            1. b.linkThe Runner receives 4[click] on each of their turns.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                            2. 1.11.3.linkPlayers can gain, lose, or spend clicks.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                1. a.linkA player gains clicks whenever the number of clicks they have is increased.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  1. b.linkIf a player loses or spends clicks, the number of clicks they have is reduced by that amount. The terms "lose" and "spend" are not synonymous for the purposes of meeting conditions and restrictions of card abilities.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    1. c.linkPaid abilities that begin with [click] are actions and have special timing rules (see section 5.2). Aside from taking actions, there are no special restrictions to how or when a player can spend their clicks during their turn.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    2. 1.11.4.linkSome cards have the subtype priority and the text, "Play only as your first [click]." A player can only play a priority card using the basic action to play an event or operation, and only if they have not spent any other clicks that turn. Losing clicks does not affect a player's ability to play a priority card.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      1.12. Objectslink

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      1. 1.12.1.linkAn object is an occurrence of a card or counter existing in a particular zone. When a card or counter moves from one zone to another, it becomes a new object.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        1. 1.12.2.linkRestrictions and effects on a card or counter only apply for as long as that card or counter remains the same object. Cards and counters have no memory of the objects they were in the past.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            1. Example: The Corp uses the first ability on Vaporframe Fabricator, which specifies that it can only be used once per turn, and trashes Vaporframe Fabricator during the installation process. Then the Corp plays Restore, reinstalling the same copy of Vaporframe Fabricator from Archives. Even though it is the same physical card, the reinstalled Vaporframe Fabricator is a new object, and its "once per turn" ability is available to be used this turn.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          1. a.linkAn ability that moves cards can identify the new objects that those cards become and continue to act on them.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            1. Example: The Corp plays Priority Construction, installing a piece of ice from HQ. That ice is now a new object in the play area, but Priority Construction's second instruction can still find it and place advancement counters on it.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        2. 1.12.3.linkA card that moves from its location to a hidden or secret location becomes a new object, even if the new location is in the same zone.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          1. Example: The Corp scores Accelerated Beta Test, looks at the top 3 cards of R&D, and installs and rezzes a piece of ice from among them. As a chain reaction, the Corp then uses The Foundry: Refining the Process to search R&D, with the result that the other cards currently being looked at by Accelerated Beta Test are shuffled along with the rest of R&D. Since the cards were moved to an unknown location in R&D, Accelerated Beta Test can no longer act on them, so those cards can no longer be looked at and will not be installed or trashed.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          2. Example: The top card of R&D in the current game state is an object. So is the 2nd card from the top of R&D, the 3rd card, and so on. If the Corp plays Precognition and rearranges the top 5 cards of R&D, the Runner will not know which cards correspond to which objects in the previous order, so the cards become new objects under their new order.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        3. 1.12.4.linkA card or counter that moves to a known location in the same zone is still the same object.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          1. Example: The Runner has chosen a piece of ice with Femme Fatale, and the Corp uses Thimblerig's ability to move that ice to another location. But the ice has not left the play area, so it is still the same object and the Runner can still use Femme Fatale's ability to bypass it.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        4. 1.12.5.linkA card that is turned faceup or facedown is still the same object.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          1. Example: The Corp uses Vaporframe Fabricator, installing a piece of ice at no cost, and then plays Divert Power to derez Vaporframe Fabricator and rez their newly-installed ice at a discount. The Corp can rez Vaporframe Fabricator again, but since it is still the same object, its "once per turn" ability cannot be used again this turn.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        5. 1.12.6.linkWhen a card or counter becomes a new object, its previous object ceases to exist, but can still be remembered by rules or abilities that refer to past game states.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            1. Example: The Runner plays Bravado. During the run, a piece of ice that the Runner has already passed is trashed. When the run ends, Bravado's ability must determine how many pieces of ice the Runner passed during that run. It does this by reviewing the game history and counting each distinct ice object that the Runner passed. Even though the object corresponding to the trashed ice no longer exists in the present game state, Bravado can still count it.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            2. Example: The Runner trashes the top card of R&D while accessing it. The object corresponding to that card in its location on top of R&D ceases to exist, but still counts against the number of cards the Runner can access from R&D during this breach.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          1. a.linkAn object that has ceased to exist still counts as the source for any active lingering effects created by that object. See section 9.10 for information about lingering effects.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            1. Example: The Runner runs a server, steals an agenda, and accesses a rezzed copy of AMAZE Amusements. The Runner trashes AMAZE Amusements, and the object they had accessed ceases to exist, while the trashed card becomes a new object in Archives. The source of the persistent ability created by the trashing is the original object in the root of the server, so the reference to "this server" in the persistent ability still refers to the attacked server, and the Runner will take 2 tags when the run ends.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        1.13. Host, Hosted, and Hostinglink

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        1. 1.13.1.linkWhenever an object is "placed" or "loaded" onto a card, a host relationship is created between those two objects. The object placed on top of a card is hosted on that card. The card onto which the other object is placed is the host.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            1. a.linkOnly cards in score areas and the play area can host objects.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            2. 1.13.2.linkThe state of being hosted is distinct, but not exclusive from, the state of being installed.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                1. a.linkIf an ability instructs a player to host a card that is not installed without reference to installing it, the hosted card does not become installed.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  1. b.linkIf an installed Corp card becomes hosted on a Runner card, the Corp card becomes uninstalled.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    1. c.linkIf a card is installed from a hosted state, it ceases to be hosted. The hosting relationship ends at step step 8.5.16a of the installation.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    2. 1.13.3.linkAn object can only be hosted on a single card at any given time.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      1. 1.13.4.linkA card can host any number of other objects, except where explicitly restricted by a card ability.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        1. 1.13.5.linkAny card in an eligible location can act as a host, but a host relationship can only be created or permitted by a card ability.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            1. a.linkIf a card has an ability describing the types and/or numbers of cards it can host, but it does not have an ability that directly hosts cards onto itself, then the card is permitted as an eligible installation destination for the types of cards listed, up to the number specified. A host card is chosen as an installation destination during step 8.5.16b of the installation process.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              1. Example: Off-Campus Apartment has the ability, "Off-Campus Apartment can host any number of connections." This means that whenever the Runner installs a connection card, they can choose to install that card into the play area hosted on Off-Campus Apartment or as normal directly into the play area.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            2. b.linkIf a card has an ability describing cards it can host, but also one or more abilities that can create host relationships onto itself, then it only allows cards to become hosted on it through those abilities. A card cannot be installed directly onto the card through an unrelated install effect.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              1. Example: Glenn Station reads, "Glenn Station can host a single card", but also has a paid ability that hosts a card on itself. Therefore, Glenn Station only lets the Corp host cards through that paid ability, not through an install action.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            3. c.linkIf a card has an ability stipulating that it can only be installed hosted onto another card, then during the installation process a player that wishes to install that card must choose a valid destination matching the description provided. If no such destination exists before the installation process begins, the card cannot be installed.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              1. Example: Egret states, "Install only on a rezzed piece of ice." The Runner can only install Egret if there is an installed, rezzed piece of ice available before the installation process begins; otherwise, it is illegal for the Runner to install Egret.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            4. d.linkSome operations and events convert themselves into condition counters and install themselves hosted onto other cards. An operation or event can never be installed through an install effect; it can only become an installed counter through its conversion ability. See rule 10.1.4.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            5. 1.13.6.linkCards can be hosted faceup or facedown.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                1. a.linkUnless otherwise specified, a card that is hosted while it is being installed is hosted onto the destination card in the same faceup or facedown status it would normally be installed in.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  1. b.linkUnless otherwise specified, a card that is hosted without being installed is hosted faceup.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    1. c.linkLike other facedown installed cards, installed cards hosted facedown are distinct. The order in which they were installed (or turned facedown) is open information.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      1. d.linkCards hosted facedown without being installed must be kept in distinct groups according to their host. Cards within such a group are not ordered and can be freely arranged by their controller.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      2. 1.13.7.linkOnce a card is installed, hosted or not, a player cannot change that card's hosted status unless a card ability explicitly directs it to be hosted onto a new card.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        1. 1.13.8.linkHost relationships are not transitive. If card A is hosted on card B, and card B is hosted on card C, card A is not considered to be hosted on card C.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          1. Example: If the Runner installs a Leprechaun hosted on a Dhegdheer, programs hosted on Leprechaun do not have their install costs reduced because they are hosted on Leprechaun and not on Dhegdheer.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        2. 1.13.9.linkIf an ability on a card refers to a "hosted" card or counter, that ability only references objects hosted on that card.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          1. 1.13.10.linkHosted objects can be removed or spent from their host without affecting the host.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            1. 1.13.11.linkIf a host card changes zones, except by moving from a player's score area to another player's score area, all objects hosted on that card (and all objects hosted on those objects, and so on) are trashed during the next checkpoint. This cannot be prevented. See section 10.3 for details on checkpoints.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              1. Example: The Runner has an installed copy of Detente with Corp cards hosted on it. They play Rejig, adding Detente to their grip. The hosted Corp cards are trashed.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              2. Example: The Runner has Next Big Thing in their score area with a hosted agenda counter. The Corp plays IP Enforcement to install that agenda. The hosted agenda counter will be trashed after step 8.5.16d of the installation.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              3. Example: The Runner has Next Big Thing in their score area with a hosted agenda counter. The Corp plays Exchange of Information to swap that agenda to their own score area. The agenda counter remains hosted on Next Big Thing.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            2. 1.13.12.linkCondition counters are the only type of counter that can host other objects. Hosting on condition counters follows the same rules as hosting on cards.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              1.14. Ownership and Controllink

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              1. 1.14.1.linkThe owner of a card is the player who provided that card at the start of the game as their identity, part of their deck, or an extra card along with their deck.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  1. a.linkA card that is converted into a counter retains its owner.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    1. b.linkNo player owns counters that are not converted cards.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    2. 1.14.2.linkThe controller of an object is the player responsible for that object.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        1. a.linkThe controller of a card in the play area is the player who installed or placed it there.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          1. b.linkThe Corp controls each agenda in the Corp's score area. The Runner controls each agenda in the Runner's score area.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            1. c.linkCards in other zones are controlled by their owner.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              1. d.linkEach player controls the credits in their credit pool.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                1. e.linkThe Corp controls each bad publicity counter. The Runner controls each tag counter. However, see rule 10.5.5 and rule 10.6.3 regarding paying costs that involve tags and bad publicity, respectively.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  1. f.linkThe controller of a counter hosted on a card is the player who controls the host card.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    1. g.linkClick counters and core damage counters are gameplay aids only and have no controller.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    2. 1.14.3.linkA player can only pay costs using objects they control.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      1. 1.14.4.linkThe controller of an ability is the player responsible for that ability. By default, this is the player who controls the ability's source. See also section 9.1.3. A player can only use abilities they control.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          1. a.linkUnless specifically stated otherwise, abilities on agendas are controlled by the Corp, even for agendas in the Runner's score area.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            1. b.linkSome abilities state that they can only be used by a specific player. The specified player controls each such ability, even if they do not control its source.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            2. 1.14.5.linkUnless otherwise noted, the controller of an ability carries out its effects and makes any choices required. If a player is specified to perform all or part of an effect, the specified player carries out that part of the effect and makes any choices required instead.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                1. Example: Rototurret's first subroutine reads, "Trash 1 installed program." Since Rototurret is a Corp card, the Corp chooses which installed program to trash. Conversely, Bulwark's first subroutine reads, "The Runner trashes 1 installed program." Since the Runner is specified to be carrying out this effect, they choose which of their installed programs to trash.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              1. a.linkSome trigger conditions care about effects performed by a particular player. These conditions are only met when that player is the one to carry out the relevant effect.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                1. Example: The Corp has a rezzed Hostile Infrastructure. Apocalypse does not specify who trashes the cards, so the Runner is responsible for the trashing and Hostile Infrastructure meets its trigger condition.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                2. Example: Alice Merchant states that "the Corp must trash 1 card from HQ", so the Corp carries out this effect even though Alice Merchant is a Runner card, and therefore Hostile Infrastructure does not meet its trigger condition.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            1.15. Targetslink

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            1. 1.15.1.linkMany abilities require players to choose 1 or more objects or subroutines to affect. Each object and subroutine chosen for an ability is a target of that ability.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                1. Example: Top Hat reads in part, "you may choose 1 of the top 5 cards of R&D and access it." The target of this instruction is the card in R&D the Runner chooses.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                2. Example: One of the subroutines on Colossus reads in part, "Trash 1 installed program and 1 installed resource." The targets of this subroutine are the two cards that will be trashed.
